summary.grammarTip:
Der Nominativ (The Subject)

The Nominative case identifies the subject of a sentence (who or what is doing the action). Adjective endings change based on the article and noun gender.

GenderDefinite Article (der)Indefinite Article (ein)
Masculine (der)-e (der alte Mann)-er (ein alter Mann)
Feminine (die)-e (die schöne Frau)-e (eine schöne Frau)
Neuter (das)-e (das kleine Kind)-es (ein kleines Kind)
Plural (die)-en (die neuen Schuhe)-en (keine neuen Schuhe)

Verbs like sein (to be) and werden (to become) also use the nominative for the object.

Der Akkusativ (The Direct Object)

The Accusative case marks the direct object (what receives the action). Ask 'Wen/Was?' (Whom/What?). Only the masculine forms change.

GenderDefinite Article (den)Indefinite Article (einen)
Masculine (den)-en (den alten Mann)-en (einen alten Mann)
Feminine (die)-e (die schöne Frau)-e (eine schöne Frau)
Neuter (das)-e (das kleine Kind)-es (ein kleines Kind)
Plural (die)-en (die neuen Schuhe)-en (keine neuen Schuhe)

Prepositions like für, durch, gegen, ohne, um always take the Accusative.

Der Dativ (The Indirect Object)

The Dative case marks the indirect object (to/for whom the action is done). Ask 'Wem?' (To whom?). All genders change.

GenderDefinite Article (dem)Indefinite Article (einem)
Masculine (dem)-en (dem alten Mann)-en (einem alten Mann)
Feminine (der)-en (der schönen Frau)-en (einer schönen Frau)
Neuter (dem)-en (dem kleinen Kind)-en (einem kleinen Kind)
Plural (den +n)-en (den neuen Schuhen)-en (keinen neuen Schuhen)

Verbs like helfen, danken, gehören and prepositions like aus, bei, mit, nach, seit, von, zu always take the Dative.
